" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no inquiries regarding the "new extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no inquiries regarding the "new extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (refer to the last paragraph of the explanation for full Regulation details) (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel -------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------ (2) Trip fuel “from departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome is 5352 kg.” 5352 kg (3) Contingency fuel “Contingency should be 5 % of trip fuel.” 5% x 5352 kg = 267.6 kg (4) Alternate fuel “Alternate fuel is 4380 kg. “ 4380 kg (5) Final reserve fuel “for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions” 30 min x 6000 kg/h = 3000 kg TOTAL -------------------------------------------------------------------------- 12 999.5 kg Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel, which should not be less than the amount expected to be used prior to takeoff. Local conditions at the departure aerodrome and auxiliary power unit (APU) consumption should be taken into account. (2) Trip fuel, which should include: (i) fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. (3) Contingency fuel, except as provided for in (b), which should be the higher of: (i) Either: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 5 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight; (B) not less than 3 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 3 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that an en-route alternate (ERA) aerodrome is available; (C) an amount of fuel sufficient for 20 minutes flying time based upon the planned trip fuel consumption, provided that the operator has established a fuel consumption monitoring programme for individual aeroplanes and uses valid data determined by means of such a programme for fuel calculation; or (D) an amount of fuel based on a statistical method that ensures an appropriate statistical coverage of the deviation from the planned to the actual trip fuel. This method is used to monitor the fuel consumption on each city pair/aeroplane combination and the operator uses this data for a statistical analysis to calculate contingency fuel for that city pair/aeroplane combination; (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m), above the destination aerodrome in standard conditions. (4) Alternate fuel, which should: (i) include: (A) fuel for a missed approach from the applicable DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome to missed approach altitude, taking into account the complete missed approach procedure; (B) fuel for climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (C) fuel for cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing; (D) fuel for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (E) fuel for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome; (ii) where two destination alternate aerodromes are required, be sufficient to proceed to the alternate aerodrome that requires the greater amount of alternate fuel. (5) Final reserve fuel, which should be: (i) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. (6) The minimum additional fuel, which should permit: (i) the aeroplane to descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of engine failure or loss of pressurisation, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the route, and (A) hold there for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions; and (B) make an approach and landing, except that additional fuel is only required if the minimum amount of fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(2) to (a)(5) is not sufficient for such an event; and (ii) holding for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, when a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome. (7) Extra fuel, which should be at the discretion of the commander

content.question:
Given the following information, select the correct statement regarding the Alternate Fuel for a Commercial Air Transport flight for which an En-Route Alternate (ERA) aerodrome is considered.
ERA for 3 % Contingency fuel: LFPR
Destination aerodrome: DESA
Destination alternate aerodrome: ALTB

options.A: Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from a point en-route to LFPR and then from DESA to ALTB, so it includes the flight time to all alternate aerodromes.
options.B: The fuel for a diversion to LFPR is included in the Trip Fuel. Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from DESA to ALTB.
options.C: Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from LFPR to DESA in the event of an en-route diversion to LFPR and then sufficient to fly from DESA to ALTB.
options.D: Alternate Fuel must be sufficient to fly from DESA to LFPR or from DESA to ALTB, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel.

key_points: Under normal fuel planning rules, contingency can be calculated in a number of different ways
The standard option is 5% of the trip fuel
However, there is an option to use 3% of the trip fuel
learning.explanation: Under normal fuel planning rules, contingency can be calculated in a number of different ways. The standard option is 5% of the trip fuel. However, there is an option to use 3% of the trip fuel. Use of this option requires the selection of an En-Route Alternate (ERA) aerodrome. Where this alternate needs to be, there are rules which must be followed. The aircraft is not intended to fly to the ERA (LFPR) and, if required due to excessive fuel consumption using the contingency fuel, then the Trip Fuel will be used to divert to the ERA LFPR. Alternate Fuel is the amount of fuel required to fly from the missed approach at destination DESA to the destination alternate ALTB.

key_points: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net
You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks

learning.explanation: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net. You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks. Alternate fuel is the fuel required from the missed approach point to the nominated alternate, including the fuel required for climb, cruise, descent, approach and landing. According to the OPS 1.375 "In-flight fuel management": The flight must be conducted so that the expected usable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome is not less than: (i) the required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, or (ii) the final reserve fuel, if no alternate aerodrome is required.

content.question:
A piston-engined aeroplane on an IFR Commercial Air Transport flight arrives at its destination with the minimum fuel on board. During the approach procedure, the aircraft is forced to divert from the missed approach point to the alternate. Given the following information:
Trip Fuel: 235 litres
Alternate Fuel: 38 litres
Fuel for go around and one approach: 22 litres
Fuel flow at cruise speed: 80 l/h
Fuel flow at holding speed: 60 l/h
The minimum fuel required at the destination is (1) _____ and the minimum fuel required at the alternate is (2) _____.

key_points: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net
You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks
According to the OPS 1
learning.explanation: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net. You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks. According to the OPS 1.375 "In-flight fuel management-Aeroplane": The flight must be conducted so that the expected usable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome is not less than: (i) the required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, or (ii) the final reserve fuel, if no alternate aerodrome is required. Final reserve fuel for a piston-engined aeroplane is the minimum fuel required to fly for 45 minutes: 45/60 hr x Holding Fuel flow = 45/60 hr x 60 l/h = 45 l. Thus, the minimum fuel required at the: Destination is: Final Reserve Fuel + Alternate Fuel = 45 litres + 38 litres = 83 litres. Alternate is: Final Reserve Fuel = 45 litres. NOTE: Regarding the Final Reserve Fuel, for an aircraft with reciprocating engine, the definition just says that "It is equal with an amount of fuel to fly for 45 minutes". The selection between the Cruise Fuel Flow and the Holding Fuel Flow is according to the correct answer provided by feedback. Any feedback with the exact wording would be appreciated so as to make clear which fuel flow must be applied in each case.

content.question:
A Commercial Air Transport operation is to be pre-positioned to a remote operating location in mountainous terrain. The commander wishes to take as much extra fuel as possible. Given the following information, determine the maximum amount of Extra Fuel (including the fuel penalty) that the Commander can upload:
MTOM: 6250 lb
MLM: 4500 lb
ZFEM: 3825 lb
Planned T/O fuel: 705 lb
Trip fuel: 375 lb
Fuel tank capacity: 1100 lb
Fuel burn correction per 100 lb of extra fuel based upon: TOM +9.1 lb and LM +10 lb

key_points: The maximum amount of fuel that can be carried is limited by the maximum take-off and landing masses as well as the tank capacity
The corresponding possible amount of extra fuel is obtained by subtracting the minimum required fuel as described above from the maximum permissible fuel load
MTOM limit: The actual take-off mass (ATOM) for a planned flight can be found by adding the minimum required take-off fuel to the zero fuel mass (ZFM)
learning.explanation: The maximum amount of fuel that can be carried is limited by the maximum take-off and landing masses as well as the tank capacity. The corresponding possible amount of extra fuel is obtained by subtracting the minimum required fuel as described above from the maximum permissible fuel load. MTOM limit: The actual take-off mass (ATOM) for a planned flight can be found by adding the minimum required take-off fuel to the zero fuel mass (ZFM). The amount of extra fuel that can be added is the difference between this ATOM and the maximum take-off mass (MTOM): ATOM = 3825 lb + 705 lb = 4 530 lb MTOM - ATOM = 6 250 lb - 4 530 lb = 1 720 lb The take-off limit would allow us to carry 1 720 lb of extra fuel. MLM limit: The actual landing mass (ALM) is equal to the ATOM minus the planned trip fuel. The amount of extra fuel that can be added is the difference between this ALM and the maximum landing mass (MLM): ALM = 4 530 lb - 375 lb = 4 155 lb MLM - ALM = 4 500 lb - 4 155 lb = 345 lb That means that 345 lb of extra fuel are allowed to remain in the tanks upon arrival. However, this is not the amount of extra fuel that may be loaded due to the fuel penalty. Rule of thumb: to calculate fuel penalty, use the following formula: (MLM extra / 100) x Y - where "Y" is the variable given by the question, in this case = 10 ( 345/100) x 10 = 34.5 lb Therefore, the extra fuel that can be loaded is: 345 lb + 34.5 lb = 379.5 lb Fuel tank capacity: Maximum Tank Capacity - (Take off fuel + Taxi fuel) 1 100 lb - (705 lb) = 395 lb

A predetermined point is selected along the route at which the crew decides whether continuing to the intended destination reasonably assures successful landing or whether the alternate destination is a safer choice. Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy (c) Predetermined point (PDP) procedure If the operator’s fuel policy includes planning to a destination alternate aerodrome where the distance between the destination aerodrome and the destination alternate aerodrome is such that a flight can only be routed via a predetermined point to one of these aerodromes, the amount of usable fuel, on board for departure, should be the greater of (c)(1) or (c)(2): (1) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; (ii) trip fuel from the departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome, via the predetermined point; (iii) contingency fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(3); (iv) additional fuel if required, but not less than: (A) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes plus 15 % of the flight time planned to be spent at cruising level or 2 hours, whichever is less; or (B) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 2 hours at normal cruise consumption above the destination aerodrome, this should not be less than final reserve fuel; and (v) extra fuel if required by the commander. (2) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; (ii) trip fuel from the departure aerodrome to the destination alternate aerodrome, via the predetermined point; (iii) contingency fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(3); (iv) additional fuel if required, but not less than: (A) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines: fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (B) for aeroplanes with turbine engines: fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above the destination alternate aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, this should not be less than final reserve fuel; and (v) extra fuel if required by the commander.

You plan a flight from Athens to Paris and back. Due to refueling problems in Paris, you decide to take fuel for the flight from Paris to Athens on the outbound leg, so that no fueling is necessary in Paris.

key_points: Aviation is a very competitive market and each airline needs to minimise operating costs, in order to keep its ticket prices as competitive as possible
Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport
However, the additional fuel carried when doing fuel tankering increases the aircraft's weight and therefore increases its fuel consumption, resulting in additional CO2 emissions
learning.explanation: Aviation is a very competitive market and each airline needs to minimise operating costs, in order to keep its ticket prices as competitive as possible. Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport. However, the additional fuel carried when doing fuel tankering increases the aircraft's weight and therefore increases its fuel consumption, resulting in additional CO2 emissions. Fuel tankering provides financial savings mainly due to fuel price differences at airports. It is done in 90% of cases for fuel price reasons, and only in 10% of cases for social disruption, technical failures at the refuelling facility, fuel shortages, risks of delays, or contaminated fuel at destination airports. For fuel tankering to be economical the fuel price at the destination must be greater than the break even fuel price. You may tanker fuel in case of/if: You will not tanker fuel if: Adverse destination weather The cost of fuel is higher at the Departure than destination aerodrome Fuel shortages at destination Low performance – not sufficient to clear MOCA with one engine inop The cost of fuel at destination is higher than at the departure aerodrome Estimated landing mass at destination equals maximum landing mass

You are cruising at FL380 with a twin-engined jet aeroplane. Determine the fuel consumed at FL380 until the top of descent (TOD). The distance travelled at FL380 is 240 NM, the TAT is -44°C and the aeroplane mass is 50 000 kg.

learning.explanation: To begin, we will determine the fuel consumption for both engines during the flight at FL380 and a Total Air Temperature (TAT) of -44°C, using the provided table. Given an aircraft mass of 50 000 kg, please consult the relevant section of the attached table: 38 000 ft (-32°C) FF/ENG (kg/h) 923 The FF/ENG value provided is not the final figure. Please direct your attention to the accompanying note situated in the table: "Increase/decrease fuel flow by 3% per 10°C above/below standard TAT." Based on the given information, the TAT at FL380 is -44°C, which is 12°C lower than the standard TAT of -32°C. Consequently, the final FF/ENG is calculated as follows: Final FF/ENG = 923 kg/h - 3.6% of 923 kg/h = 889.772 kg/h The aircraft has two engines, therefore the total fuel flow is: 2 x 889.772 kg/h = 1779.5 kg/h Once more, we will make use of the attached table to establish the True Airspeed (TAS) at FL380. Kindly consult the relevant section of the attached table: 38 000 ft (-32°C) TAS (kt) 433 This, however, is not the final TAS value for the particular flight. Please refer to the accompanying note positioned above the table: "Increase/decrease TAS by 1 knot for every 1°C above/below standard TAT." According to the information provided, the TAT at FL380 is -44°C, which is 12°C lower than the standard TAT. Consequently, the final TAS is calculated as follows: Final TAS = 433 kt - 12 kt = 421 kt At a speed of 421 kt, the duration needed to cover a distance of 240 NM can be calculated as follows: Time = Distance/Speed = (240 NM)/(421 kt) = 0.57 hours Therefore, with a fuel flow rate of 1779.5 kg/h, we can determine the anticipated fuel consumption for the flight at FL380: Fuel consumption = (0.57h) x (1779.5 kg/h) = 1014 kg

learning.explanation: In some cases, it is commercially advantageous to carry more fuel than the legal minimum because the cost of fuel at the destination airport is significantly higher than at the departure airport. For instance, this is often the case with certain Mediterranean islands. It can be cheaper to carry (tanker) as much fuel as possible from the departure airport rather than refuel at the destination. You may also need to tanker fuel if the destination airport is short on fuel or unable to provide it, due to reasons such as a workers' strike or a broken fuel pipeline. However, carrying more fuel than legally required incurs a commercial penalty because more fuel is burned carrying the additional mass. Therefore, you need to calculate whether it is worth doing. In an airline operation, this decision is usually made by the operations department, and you would notice from the operational flight plan that you are tankering fuel.

Local conditions at the departure aerodrome and auxiliary power unit (APU) consumption should be taken into account. (2) Trip fuel, which should include: (i) fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. (3) Contingency fuel, except as provided for in (b), which should be the higher of: (i) Either: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 5 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight; (B) not less than 3 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 3 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that an en-route alternate (ERA) aerodrome is available; (C) an amount of fuel sufficient for 20 minutes flying time based upon the planned trip fuel consumption, provided that the operator has established a fuel consumption monitoring programme for individual aeroplanes and uses valid data determined by means of such a programme for fuel calculation; or (D) an amount of fuel based on a statistical method that ensures an appropriate statistical coverage of the deviation from the planned to the actual trip fuel. This method is used to monitor the fuel consumption on each city pair/aeroplane combination and the operator uses this data for a statistical analysis to calculate contingency fuel for that city pair/aeroplane combination; (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m), above the destination aerodrome in standard conditions. (4) Alternate fuel, which should: (i) include: (A) fuel for a missed approach from the applicable DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome to missed approach altitude, taking into account the complete missed approach procedure; (B) fuel for climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (C) fuel for cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing; (D) fuel for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (E) fuel for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome; (ii) where two destination alternate aerodromes are required, be sufficient to proceed to the alternate aerodrome that requires the greater amount of alternate fuel. (5) Final reserve fuel, which should be: (i) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. (6) The minimum additional fuel, which should permit: (i) the aeroplane to descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of engine failure or loss of pressurisation, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the route, and (A) hold there for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions; and (B) make an approach and landing, except that additional fuel is only required if the minimum amount of fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(2) to (a)(5) is not sufficient for such an event; and (ii) holding for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, when a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome. (7) Extra fuel, which should be at the discretion of the commander

content.question:
An aircraft planning to fly a total distance of 450 NM, after flying for 1 hour 20 minutes it covers 160 NM and its actual fuel remaining is 890 I. Given the following information and assuming that the actual fuel consumption remains at the same rate, what will be the actual fuel remaining at destination?
Average TAS: 145 kt
Average wind component: 25 kt headwind
Trip Fuel: 1 350 l
Planned average fuel flow: 360 l/h

key_points: Actual Fuel Consumption in 1 hr 20 min (80 min): Trip fuel - Fuel remaining after 1 hr 20 min = 1350 l - 890 l = 460 l
Actual Fuel Flow: 460 l x 60/80 = 345 l/hr
Groundspeed: TAS - Headwind component = 145 kt - 25 kt = 120 kt
learning.explanation: Actual Fuel Consumption in 1 hr 20 min (80 min): Trip fuel - Fuel remaining after 1 hr 20 min = 1350 l - 890 l = 460 l. Actual Fuel Flow: 460 l x 60/80 = 345 l/hr. Groundspeed: TAS - Headwind component = 145 kt - 25 kt = 120 kt. Remaining Distance: Trip distance - Distance flown = 450 NM - 160 NM = 290 NM. Remaining Flight time: Remaining Distance / GS = 290 NM / 120 kt = 2.41 hr or 145 min. Required Fuel until Destination: Remaining Flight time x Actual Fuel Flow = 2.41 hr x 345 l/hr = 835 l. Finally, the Actual Fuel Remaining at destination will be: 890 l - 835 l = 55 l.

content.question:
An IFR flight from departure A to destination B applying the decision point procedure (DPP) is planned with a decision point DP and en-route alternate C.How much trip fuel is required given the following information?
Distance A to B: 2 300 NM
Distance A to C: 1 300 NM
Distance A to DP: 1 150 NM
TAS: 470 kt
TWC: 32 kt
Fuel flow: 2 600 kg/h

key_points: The question refers to the Reduced Contingency Fuel (RCF) procedure, which historically, under JAR OPS the same rule was referred to as the Decision Point Procedure (DPP)

When an operator's fuel policy includes pre-flight planning using RCF procedure to a Destination B aerodrome (commercial destination), a Decision Point (DP) will be defined enroute along with a Destination C aerodrome (optional refueling destination), the amount of usable fuel on board for departure, shall be the greater of 1 or 2 below: Sum 1: Taxy fuel Trip fuel to Dest B via DP Contingency fuel not less than 5% of the consumption from DP to Dest B Alternate fuel (if required) Final Reserve fuel Additional fuel Extra fuel (if required) Sum 2: Taxy fuel Trip fuel to Dest C via DP Contingency fuel not less than 5% of the consumption from Dep to Dest C Alternate fuel (if a Dest C alternate required) Final Reserve fuel Additional fuel Extra fuel (if required) But, the question asks only for the Trip fuel and will be the greater of Trip 1 and Trip 2
Trip 1 (to Dest B via DP) is: (Trip Time / GS) x Fuel Flow = (Distance A to B / GS) x Fuel Flow =[2 300 NM / (470 kt + 32 kt)] x 2 600 kg/hr = 11 913 kg
learning.explanation: The question refers to the Reduced Contingency Fuel (RCF) procedure, which historically, under JAR OPS the same rule was referred to as the Decision Point Procedure (DPP). When an operator's fuel policy includes pre-flight planning using RCF procedure to a Destination B aerodrome (commercial destination), a Decision Point (DP) will be defined enroute along with a Destination C aerodrome (optional refueling destination), the amount of usable fuel on board for departure, shall be the greater of 1 or 2 below: Sum 1: Taxy fuel Trip fuel to Dest B via DP Contingency fuel not less than 5% of the consumption from DP to Dest B Alternate fuel (if required) Final Reserve fuel Additional fuel Extra fuel (if required) Sum 2: Taxy fuel Trip fuel to Dest C via DP Contingency fuel not less than 5% of the consumption from Dep to Dest C Alternate fuel (if a Dest C alternate required) Final Reserve fuel Additional fuel Extra fuel (if required) But, the question asks only for the Trip fuel and will be the greater of Trip 1 and Trip 2. Trip 1 (to Dest B via DP) is: (Trip Time / GS) x Fuel Flow = (Distance A to B / GS) x Fuel Flow =[2 300 NM / (470 kt + 32 kt)] x 2 600 kg/hr = 11 913 kg. Trip 2 (to Dest C via DP) is: (Trip Time / GS) x Fuel Flow = (Distance A to C / GS) x Fuel Flow =[1 300 NM / (470 kt + 32 kt)] x 2 600 kg/hr = 6 733 kg. Thus, the required trip fuel applying the decision point procedure (DPP) is 11 913 kg.

learning.explanation: A general rule applies for all aircraft types: "An aircraft should always land with final reserve fuel intact." Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but it is carried in order to provide a final safety net. The pilot must always plan to put the aeroplane on the ground with at least final resrve fuel in the tanks. If it looks like you will land with less than final reserve, EU OPS says that you must declare an emergency. Final Reserve fuel is: For aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes For aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. For this question, the minimum amount of fuel required on arrival at the destination aerodrome/heliport is the Final Reserve Fuel 1075 kg.

content.question:
Given the following information for a Commercial Air Transport flight, what is the time (in minutes) needed from the destination to the alternate aerodrome? Assume an operation with a Performance Class A aeroplane applying the Basic Fuel Scheme or with a helicopter (the basic fuel planning provisions are the same).
Missed approach at the destination: 6 min
Climb to cruise level: 8 min
Cruise distance: 55 NM
Cruise TAS: 165 kt
Headwind: 10 kt
Expected holding at the alternate: 10 min
Descent to the alternate: 6 min
Approach to the alternate: 6 min

key_points: The time required from the destination to the alternate aerodrome is the sum of the following: Time for a missed approach from the applicable MDA/DA at the destination aerodrome to the missed approach altitude: 6 min
Time to climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing: 8 min
Time to cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing: Cruise distance / Groundspeed = 55 NM / (165 kt - 10 kt) = 0
learning.explanation: The time required from the destination to the alternate aerodrome is the sum of the following: Time for a missed approach from the applicable MDA/DA at the destination aerodrome to the missed approach altitude: 6 min. Time to climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing: 8 min. Time to cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing: Cruise distance / Groundspeed = 55 NM / (165 kt - 10 kt) = 0.35 hr or 21 min. Time for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure (for this question additional time for holding at the alternate is expected): 6 min + 10 min = 16 min. Time for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate: 6 min. Thus, the time required is: 6 min + 8 min + 21 min + 16 min + 6 min = 57 min.

content.question:
Which of the following circumstances would be considered suitable for fuel tankering?
1. The estimated landing mass is equal to the maximum landing mass.
2. The weather at the destination is below landing minima.
3. Unable to climb to the Minimum Obstacle Clearance Altitude (MOCA) should an engine fail.
4. There is no fuel available at the destination aerodrome.

key_points: Aviation is a very competitive market and each airline needs to minimise operating costs, in order to keep its ticket prices as competitive as possible
Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport
However, the additional fuel carried when doing fuel tankering increases the aircraft's weight and therefore increases its fuel consumption, resulting in additional CO2 emissions
learning.explanation: Aviation is a very competitive market and each airline needs to minimise operating costs, in order to keep its ticket prices as competitive as possible. Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport. However, the additional fuel carried when doing fuel tankering increases the aircraft's weight and therefore increases its fuel consumption, resulting in additional CO2 emissions. Fuel tankering provides financial savings mainly due to fuel price differences at airports. It is done in 90% of cases for fuel price reasons, and only in 10% of cases for social disruption, technical failures at the refuelling facility, fuel shortages, risks of delays, or contaminated fuel at destination airports. For fuel tankering to be economical the fuel price at the destination must be greater than the break even fuel price. You may tanker fuel in case of/if: You will not tanker fuel if: Adverse destination weather The cost of fuel is higher at the Departure than destination aerodrome Fuel shortages at destination Low performance – not sufficient to clear MOCA with one engine inop The cost of fuel at destination is higher than at the departure aerodrome Estimated landing mass at destination equals maximum landing mass

Taxi Fuel: 10L
Normal fuel consumption: 95 L/h
Holding Fuel Consumption: 76 L/h
Climb fuel: 40 L
Departure and Go Around fuel: 40 L
Approach and landing fuel: 20 L
Extra Fuel: 0 L
Discretionary Fuel: 0 L

The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel

learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. EASA AIR OPS AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel which should not be less than the amount expected to be used prior to takeoff. Local conditions at the departure aerodrome and auxiliary power unit (APU) consumption should be taken into account. (2) Trip fuel which should include: (i)fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. (3) Contingency fuel which should be the higher of: (i) Either: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 5 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight; (B) not less than 3 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 3 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that an en-route alternate (ERA) aerodrome is available; (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m), above the destination aerodrome in standard conditions. (4) Alternate fuel which should: (i) include: (A) fuel for a missed approach from the applicable DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome to missed approach altitude, taking into account the complete missed approach procedure; (B) fuel for climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (C) fuel for cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing; (D) fuel for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (E) fuel for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome; (ii) where two destination alternate aerodromes are required, be sufficient to proceed to the alternate aerodrome that requires the greater amount of alternate fuel. (5) Final reserve fuel which should be: (i) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. (6) The minimum additional fuel which should permit: (i) the aeroplane to descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of engine failure or loss of pressurisation, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the route, and (A) hold there for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions; and (B) make an approach and landing, except that additional fuel is only required if the minimum amount of fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(2) to (a)(5) is not sufficient for such an event; and (ii) holding for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, when a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome. (7) Extra fuel, which should be at the discretion of the commander. In this case: TAXI Taxi fuel is 10L. 10 L TRIP Departure + Cruise + Approach + Landing 40 L + (2 h 24 min x 95) + 20 L = 288 L CONTINGENCY The greater of: 5% of trip fuel or 5 min holding 288 x 5% = 14.4 L Or 5 min x 76 L/h = 6.3 L ALTERNATE Departure aerodrome will be used as an alternate 40 L + (2 h 24 min x 95) + 20 L = 288 L FINAL RESERVE For aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes 45 min x 76 L/h = 57 L ADDITIONAL Not required 0 L TOTAL (BLOCK FUEL) 10 L + 288 L + 14.4 L + 288 L + 57 L = 657.4 L

content.question:
For pre-flight planning purposes, what is the minimum Block Fuel required for the Commercial Air Transport flight in a Medium Range Jet Transport MRJT aeroplane, given the following information? The operator has nominated a suitable En-Route Alternate aerodrome. Assume the Basic Fuel Scheme WITHOUT variations applies.
Departure Taxi Fuel: 150 kg
Trip Fuel: 2101 kg
Alternate Fuel: 2046 kg
Destination Taxi Fuel: 250 kg
Average fuel flow: 3317 kg/h
Holding fuel flow: 2735 kg/h
Extra Fuel: 0 kg
Discretionary Fuel: 0 kg

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new
The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel
" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. Under normal fuel planning rules, contingency fuel can be calculated in a number of different ways. So far, the standard option has been to use 5% of the trip fuel. However, there is an option to use 3% of trip fuel. Use of this option requires the selection of an En-Route Alternate (ERA) aerodrome, which must cover some prerequisites: Shall be located within a circle having a radius equal to 20% of the total flight plan distance, the centre of which lies on the planned route at a distance from the destination aerodrome of 25% of the total flight plan distance, or at least 20% of the total flight plan distance plus 50 NM, whichever is greater. For this question, the Minimum Block fuel required is equal to: Taxi fuel + Trip fuel + Contingency fuel + Alternate fuel + Final Reserve fuel + Additional fuel(if required) + Extra fuel(if required) Taxi fuel = 150 kg Trip fuel = 2101 kg Contingency fuel (if an enroute alternate is available)= 3% x planned trip fuel or 5 min holding at 1500 ft above the destination aerodrome (whichever is greater) = 3% x 2101=63 kg or 5/60 x 2735 kg/hr = 228 kg. Thus, contingency fuel is 228 kg. Alternate fuel = 2046 kg Final Reserve fuel (for turbine engines) = fuel for 30 min holding at 1500 ft = 30/60 x 2735 kg/hr = 1367.5 kg. Therefore, the minimum block fuel required is: 150 kg + 2101 kg + 228 kg + 2046 kg + 1367.5 kg = 5892.5 kg, which is very close to 5893 kg.

MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel, which should not be less than the amount expected to be used prior to takeoff. Local conditions at the departure aerodrome and auxiliary power unit (APU) consumption should be taken into account. (2) Trip fuel, which should include: (i) fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. (3) Contingency fuel, except as provided for in (b), which should be the higher of: (i) Either: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 5 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight; (B) not less than 3 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 3 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that an en-route alternate (ERA) aerodrome is available; (C) an amount of fuel sufficient for 20 minutes flying time based upon the planned trip fuel consumption, provided that the operator has established a fuel consumption monitoring programme for individual aeroplanes and uses valid data determined by means of such a programme for fuel calculation; or (D) an amount of fuel based on a statistical method that ensures an appropriate statistical coverage of the deviation from the planned to the actual trip fuel. This method is used to monitor the fuel consumption on each city pair/aeroplane combination and the operator uses this data for a statistical analysis to calculate contingency fuel for that city pair/aeroplane combination; (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m), above the destination aerodrome in standard conditions. (4) Alternate fuel, which should: (i) include: (A) fuel for a missed approach from the applicable DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome to missed approach altitude, taking into account the complete missed approach procedure; (B) fuel for climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (C) fuel for cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing; (D) fuel for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (E) fuel for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome; (ii) where two destination alternate aerodromes are required, be sufficient to proceed to the alternate aerodrome that requires the greater amount of alternate fuel. (5) Final reserve fuel, which should be: (i) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. (6) The minimum additional fuel, which should permit: (i) the aeroplane to descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of engine failure or loss of pressurisation, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the route, and (A) hold there for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions; and (B) make an approach and landing, except that additional fuel is only required if the minimum amount of fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(2) to (a)(5) is not sufficient for such an event; and (ii) holding for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, when a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome. (7) Extra fuel, which should be at the discretion of the commander

content.question:
During a VFR flight at a navigational checkpoint the remaining usable fuel in tanks is 60 US gallons. The reserve fuel is 12 US gallons. According to the flight plan the remaining flight time is 1h 35min.
Calculate the highest acceptable rate of consumption possible for the rest of the trip.

key_points: The rules tell us that expected usable fuel remaining on arrrival at the destination must not be less than either: The required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, or The final reserve fuel, if no alternate aerodrome is required
For this question, no alternate is required, thus the remaining usable fuel on arrival at destination is: Remaining usable fuel in tanks - Reserve fuel = 60 USG - 12 USG = 48 USG
The remaining flight time is 1 hr and 35 min or 1
learning.explanation: The rules tell us that expected usable fuel remaining on arrrival at the destination must not be less than either: The required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, or The final reserve fuel, if no alternate aerodrome is required. For this question, no alternate is required, thus the remaining usable fuel on arrival at destination is: Remaining usable fuel in tanks - Reserve fuel = 60 USG - 12 USG = 48 USG. The remaining flight time is 1 hr and 35 min or 1.58 hr. So, with a remaining usable fuel amount of 48 USG on arrrival at the destination, the highest acceptable rate of consumption until the destination aerodrome must be: 48 USG / 1.58 hr = 30.3 USG/hr. NOTE: In many questions the Final Reserve Fuel (the fuel amount which must remain intact) is referred as "Reserve fuel".

The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. Under normal fuel planning rules, contingency can be calculated in a number of different ways. So far, the standard option has been to use 5% of the trip fuel. However, there is an option to use 3% of the trip fuel, which requires the selection of an En-Route Alternate aerodrome (ERA). The Minimum Take-Off Fuel is equal to the sum of the following: Trip fuel: Average fuel flow x Trip time = Average fuel flow x (Air distance / Estimated TAS) = 3048 kg/h x (2725 NAM / 431 kt) = 19 271 kg. OR Trip fuel: Average fuel flow x Trip time = Average fuel flow x (Route distance / Estimated GS) = 3048 kg/h x [2548 NM / (431 - 28) kt] = 19 271 kg Contingency fuel: 3% x Trip fuel = 3% x 19 271 kg = 578 kg. Alternate fuel: Average fuel flow x Estimated flight time to the alternate = 3048 kg/h x 34/60 = 1 727 kg. Final reserve: 1351 kg. Thus, totally the Minimum Take-Off Fuel required is: 19 271 kg + 578 kg + 1 727 kg + 1351 kg = 22 927 kg, which is very close to 22 929 kg.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
You are cruising at FL380 with a twin-engined jet aeroplane. Due to airspace restrictions ATC instructs you to reduce speed to Mach .786. Given the following information, what is the fuel you will use for the remainder of the cruise time?
Distance to Top-of-Descent: 310 NM
Aircraft mass: 60 000 kg
TAT: -22°C
Average wind component: 25 kt headwind
Consider a constant aircraft of mass 60 000 kg for calculation purposes.

key_points: Actual TAT at FL380 is -22o C, so it is above the standard TAT -32o C, given in the table, by 10o C
According to the table given, at FL380 with
786 Mach speed, 60 000 kg mass and TAT -32o C, the TAS is 451 kt and the Fuel Flow per engine is 1 087 kg/hr
learning.explanation: Actual TAT at FL380 is -22o C, so it is above the standard TAT -32o C, given in the table, by 10o C. According to the table given, at FL380 with.786 Mach speed, 60 000 kg mass and TAT -32o C, the TAS is 451 kt and the Fuel Flow per engine is 1 087 kg/hr. To calculate the fuel flow required for the ground distance 310 NM, the actual time flown is required: Actual time= Ground distance / Ground speed. With a 25 kt headwind, the groundspeed will be 451 - 25 = 426 kt. Applying the note, the TAS must be increased by 1 kts for each degree above standard TAT. So, it becomes: 426 + 10 = 436 kt The a/c will cover the ground distance 310 NM with 436 kt groundspeed in: 310/436 = 0.71 hour. For 0.71 hr flight time, the a/c will burn: 1 087 x 0.71 = 772 kg per engine, so both engines will burn: 772 x 2 = 1 544 kg. Applying the note, the fuel flow must be increased by 3% per 10o C above standard TAT. So, it becomes: 1 544 + (3% x 1 544) = 1 590 kg.

key_points: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net
You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks
According to the OPS 1
learning.explanation: Final Reserve Fuel is a quantity of fuel that should never be used, but is carried in order to provide a final safety net. You should always land with Final Reserve Fuel intact in the tanks. According to the OPS 1.375 "In-flight fuel management": The flight must be conducted so that the expected usable fuel remaining on arrival at the destination aerodrome is not less than: (i) the required alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel, or (ii) the final reserve fuel, if no alternate aerodrome is required. Thus, the remaining fuel upon landing at the alternate aerodrome, since the alternate fuel will have been burnt to fly from the destination to the alternate aerodrome, will NOT less than the final reserve fuel.

content.question: A jet aeroplane has a cruise fuel consumption of 4060 kg/h and a holding fuel consumption of 3690 kg/h. If the destination is an isolated airfield, the additional fuel that must be carried is:

key_points: An isolated aerodrome is one for which the alternate and final reserve fuel required to the nearest adequate destination aerodrome is more than the fuel to fly for two hours at normal cruise consumption above the destination aerodrome, including final reserve fuel, for aeroplanes with turbine engines
In other words, the pilot will always plan to arrive overhead the isolated aerodrome with at least 2 hours of fuel at cruise fuel consumption
If an operator's fuel policy includes planning to an isolated aerodrome, the last possible point of diversion to any available en-route alternate aerodrome shall be used as the pre-determined point
learning.explanation: An isolated aerodrome is one for which the alternate and final reserve fuel required to the nearest adequate destination aerodrome is more than the fuel to fly for two hours at normal cruise consumption above the destination aerodrome, including final reserve fuel, for aeroplanes with turbine engines. In other words, the pilot will always plan to arrive overhead the isolated aerodrome with at least 2 hours of fuel at cruise fuel consumption. If an operator's fuel policy includes planning to an isolated aerodrome, the last possible point of diversion to any available en-route alternate aerodrome shall be used as the pre-determined point. According to EASA Annex IV (Part-CAT): If the operator’s fuel planning policy includes an isolated aerodrome, the additional fuel, if required, must be not less than, the fuel to fly for 2 hours with normal cruise consumption above the destination aerodrome, including the Final Reserve Fuel, for turbine-engined aeroplanes. Therefore, for this question, the additional fuel that must be carried for an isolated aerodrome is: Cruise fuel consumption x 2 hours = 4 060 kg/hr x 2 hr = 8 120 kg.

key_points: To accurately determine the weight of the fuel, you need to convert the volume of fuel in liters to weight in kilograms using the provided density

Use the given density of 0
learning.explanation: To accurately determine the weight of the fuel, you need to convert the volume of fuel in liters to weight in kilograms using the provided density. Here’s the step-by-step process: Measure the total volume of fuel in liters in both the wing tanks and ACT 1. Use the given density of 0.79 kg/L to convert the volume to weight. Calculate the weight by multiplying the total volume by the density. Weight (kg) = Volume (L) × Density (kg/L) For example, if you have a total fuel volume of 1000 liters: Weight = 1000 L × 0.79 kg/L = 790 kg By multiplying the total volume by the provided density, you obtain the accurate weight of the fuel.

learning.explanation: The Minimum Block Fuel that is required at EIDW to return to LFPG is: 7 100 kg. We will assume that trip, contingency* and taxi fuel will be burnt: 230 kg + 2 933 kg + 157 kg = 3 320 kg. * We should assume contingency is burnt, because if we do use it, we will below minimum block fuel for the return. For the flight LFPG-EIDW, the crew have loaded a total of 5 226 kg. This means they will land at EIDW with 1 906 kg onboard (after burning taxi, contingency and trip fuel). For the flight back (EIDW - LFPG), the crew needs a minimum block fuel of 7 100 kg. Therefore, at LFPG, they should load 7 100 kg - 1 906 kg = 5 194 kg extra. However, carrying more fuel, adds weight to the aircraft and increases the fuel consumption. So, the fuel penalty from LFPG to EIDW must be applied. For every weight change per 1 000 kg, add 60 Kg to the Total fuel: 5 194 kg / 1 000 x 60 kg = 312 kg. Therefore, the Minimum fuel amount that must be tankered, after applying the Fuel Penalty at LFPG must be: 5 194 kg + 312 kg = 5 506 kg.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new

" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. The minimum fuel required to be on board of a jet aircraft before starting a Commercial Air Transport flight is the sum of the following: Taxy fuel: 140 kg. Trip fuel: 3 740 kg. Contingency fuel: The higher fuel amount among: "5% of the Trip fuel" : 5% x 3 740 kg = 187 kg. "5 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft above the destination aerodrome" : 5/60 hr x 2 132 kg/h = 178 kg. Alternate fuel: 936 kg. Final Reserve Fuel: "30 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft above aerodrome elevation" = 30/60 x 2 132 kg/h = 1 066 kg. Thus, the minimum fuel required is: 140 kg + 3 740 kg + 187 kg + 936 kg + 1 066 kg = 6 069 kg.

content.question: An aircraft is required by ATC to fly at a speed faster than planned for a short period of time, resulting in a higher fuel burn. This unforeseen factor has an influence on the fuel consumption but is accounted for in the..

key_points: Contingency fuel is an amount of fuel to cater for things that don't go to plan

It is carried to account for additional enroute fuel consumption caused by unforeseen factors such as stronger headwinds than planned, re-routing, a lower flight level than expected, higher speed than planned or perhaps you are just late and need to make up time

Generally, according to ICAO Annex 6, the recommended minimum contingency fuel is the greater of 5% of the trip fuel or 5 minutes holding consumption at 1500' above destination airfield elevation computed based on calculated arrival weight
learning.explanation: Contingency fuel is an amount of fuel to cater for things that don't go to plan. It is carried to account for additional enroute fuel consumption caused by unforeseen factors such as stronger headwinds than planned, re-routing, a lower flight level than expected, higher speed than planned or perhaps you are just late and need to make up time. Generally, according to ICAO Annex 6, the recommended minimum contingency fuel is the greater of 5% of the trip fuel or 5 minutes holding consumption at 1500' above destination airfield elevation computed based on calculated arrival weight. However, some regulators have eliminated the minimum time requirement and some have increased the recommended time interval in their National Regulations. As well, some regulators allow contingency fuel reduction to 3% of trip fuel, or to specific time increments, with use of enroute alternates and conditional upon demonstrated performance criteria from the Operator.

Thus, it will have burnt: 1 400 lb - 350 lb = 1 050 lbs or (1 050/2
learning.explanation: The pilot estimates that the aircraft will be landing at the en route refuelling point with 350 lb on board. Thus, it will have burnt: 1 400 lb - 350 lb = 1 050 lbs or (1 050/2.2 = 477.3 kg). Also, 1 IG = 4.55 litres. So, the 40 IG fuel drums in litres are: 40 IG x 4.55 lt = 182 litres fuel drums. With Specific Gravity 0.78 kg/lt, each 182 litres fuel drum will weigh: 0.78 kg/lt x 182 lt = 142 kg. The aircraft must be refuelled with 477.3 kg at en route refuelling point using 142 kg fuel drums, then: 477.3 kg / 142 kg = 3.4 fuel drums will be required. But, the fuel drums cannot be in decimal form. Thus, the fuel drums must be at least 4 to cover the minimum refuelling requirement of 477.3 kg.

Using the rule of three, we can say that if the aircraft consumes 2.5 tonnes of fuel in 25 minutes, then it will consume x tonnes of fuel in 66 minutes (the estimated time en-route from 44N 040W to 40N 050W). Solving for x, we get x = (2.5 x 66)/25 tonnes = 6.6 tonnes. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. Landing Mass is the mass of the aircraft on landing at destination or alternate aerodrome. The aircraft will land at the destination aerodrome with both Alternate fuel and Final Reserve fuel included in its tanks, burning all the Trip fuel, i.e. it will land with the Remaining Usable Fuel less the Remaining Trip Fuel. The Remaining Usable Fuel, 960 kg, includes Alternate Fuel, Final Reserve fuel and the Remaining Trip Fuel, which will be burnt until landing at destination. Thus, the revised estimated Landing Mass at the destination aerodrome is: DOM + Traffic Load + Remaining Usable Fuel - Remaining Trip Fuel to the destination = 4 515 kg + 2 540 kg + 960 kg - 350 kg = 7 665 kg.

(For this question use annex 033-043 and 033-055 rev. 05.11.2004).
The flight crew of a turbojet aeroplane prepares a flight using the following data:
Flight leg air distance: 2 700 NM
Flight level FL 310, true airspeed: 470 kt
Tailwind component at this level: 35 kt
Initially planned take-off mass (without extra fuel on board): 180 000 kg
Fuel price: 0.28 Euro/l at departure 0.26 Euro/l at destination
To maximize savings, the commander chooses to carry extra fuel in addition to that which is necessary. The optimum quantity of fuel which should be carried in addition to the prescribed quantity is:

options.C: The fuel transport operation is not recommended in this case.

key_points: Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport
Tankering will be considered if the cost of fuel at destination is higher than at the departure aerodrome
In this case, no calculations are needed
learning.explanation: Fuel tankering is a practice whereby an aircraft carries more fuel than required for its next flight (trip fuel + reserve) in order to reduce or avoid refuelling at the destination airport. Tankering will be considered if the cost of fuel at destination is higher than at the departure aerodrome. In this case, no calculations are needed. At departure aerodrome: Fuel price: 0.28 Euro/l and at destination: 0.26 Euro/l => Fuel is cheaper at the destination, therefore, tankering makes no sense.

The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel
" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept

The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (refer to the last paragraph of the explanation for full Regulation details) (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel Question asks for Take-Off Fuel, so Taxi is not considered. ------------------------------------------- (2) Trip fuel "Cruise fuel: 1500 kg/h Climb fuel: 400 kg Descent fuel: 200 kg Approach & landing fuel: 300 kg Time from top of climb to top of descent: 1h40" 1 h 40 x 1500 kg/h = 2500 kg 400 kg 200 kg 300 kg = 3400 kg (3) Contingency fuel "the higher of: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel (.); OR (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m)" "Holding fuel: 1 200 kg/h" (A) 5% x 3400 kg = 170 kg (B) 5 min x 1200 kg/h = 100 kg (4) Alternate fuel Alternate fuel: 2390 kg 2 390 kg (5) Final reserve fuel "(ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m)" "Holding fuel: 1 200 kg/h" 30 min x 1200 kg/h = 600 kg TOTAL -------------------------------------------------------------------------- 6560 kg Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES The operator should base the defined fuel policy, including calculation of the amount of fuel to be on board for departure, on the following planning criteria: (a) Basic procedure The usable fuel to be on board for departure should be the sum of the following: (1) Taxi fuel, which should not be less than the amount expected to be used prior to takeoff. Local conditions at the departure aerodrome and auxiliary power unit (APU) consumption should be taken into account. (2) Trip fuel, which should include: (i) fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. (3) Contingency fuel, except as provided for in (b), which should be the higher of: (i) Either: (A) 5 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 5 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight; (B) not less than 3 % of the planned trip fuel or, in the event of in-flight replanning, 3 % of the trip fuel for the remainder of the flight, provided that an en-route alternate (ERA) aerodrome is available; (C) an amount of fuel sufficient for 20 minutes flying time based upon the planned trip fuel consumption, provided that the operator has established a fuel consumption monitoring programme for individual aeroplanes and uses valid data determined by means of such a programme for fuel calculation; or (D) an amount of fuel based on a statistical method that ensures an appropriate statistical coverage of the deviation from the planned to the actual trip fuel. This method is used to monitor the fuel consumption on each city pair/aeroplane combination and the operator uses this data for a statistical analysis to calculate contingency fuel for that city pair/aeroplane combination; (ii) or an amount to fly for 5 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m), above the destination aerodrome in standard conditions. (4) Alternate fuel, which should: (i) include: (A) fuel for a missed approach from the applicable DA/H or MDA/H at the destination aerodrome to missed approach altitude, taking into account the complete missed approach procedure; (B) fuel for climb from missed approach altitude to cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (C) fuel for cruise from top of climb to top of descent, taking into account the expected routing; (D) fuel for descent from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (E) fuel for executing an approach and landing at the destination alternate aerodrome; (ii) where two destination alternate aerodromes are required, be sufficient to proceed to the alternate aerodrome that requires the greater amount of alternate fuel. (5) Final reserve fuel, which should be: (i) for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes; or (ii) for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, calculated with the estimated mass on arrival at the destination alternate aerodrome or the destination aerodrome, when no destination alternate aerodrome is required. (6) The minimum additional fuel, which should permit: (i) the aeroplane to descend as necessary and proceed to an adequate alternate aerodrome in the event of engine failure or loss of pressurisation, whichever requires the greater amount of fuel based on the assumption that such a failure occurs at the most critical point along the route, and (A) hold there for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions; and (B) make an approach and landing, except that additional fuel is only required if the minimum amount of fuel calculated in accordance with (a)(2) to (a)(5) is not sufficient for such an event; and (ii) holding for 15 minutes at 1 500 ft (450 m) above destination aerodrome elevation in standard conditions, when a flight is operated without a destination alternate aerodrome. (7) Extra fuel, which should be at the discretion of the commander

learning.explanation: The most fuel efficient pressure altitude is that which gives the greatest Groundspeed so as to fly the route distance of 300 NM at the least possible flight time, burning the least possible fuel amount, for a given power setting (45% in our case) and constant fuel flow. First of all, find the corresponding TAS for each combination of Pressure altitude and OAT given, following the steps below: Enter with the OAT from the bottom left side of the graph. Move vertically up to intersect the corresponding pressure altitude line. Continue horizontally to the right, until you intersect the corresponding power setting line (45% for this question). content.question:
Refer to figure.
You are cruising at FL380 with a twin-engined jet aeroplane. Due to airspace restrictions ATC instructs you to reduce speed to Mach .754. Given the following information, what is the fuel you will use for the remainder of the cruise time?
Distance to Top-of-Descent: 220 NM
Aircraft mass: 50 000 kg
TAT: -42°C
Average wind component: 45 kt tailwind
Consider a constant aircraft of mass 50 000 kg for calculation purposes.

key_points: Actual TAT at FL380 is -42o C, so it is below the standard TAT -32o C, given in the table, by 10o C
According to the table given, at FL380 with
754 Mach speed, 50 000 kgs mass and TAT -32o C, the TAS is 433 kt and the FuelFlow per engine is 923 kg/hr
learning.explanation: Actual TAT at FL380 is -42o C, so it is below the standard TAT -32o C, given in the table, by 10o C. According to the table given, at FL380 with.754 Mach speed, 50 000 kgs mass and TAT -32o C, the TAS is 433 kt and the FuelFlow per engine is 923 kg/hr. To calculate the fuel flow required for the ground distance 220 NM, the actual time flown is required: Actual time= Ground distance / Ground speed. With a 45 kt tailwind, the groundspeed will be 433 + 45 = 478 kts. Applying the note, the TAS must be reduced by 1 kts for each degree below standard TAT. So, it becomes: 478 - 10 = 468 kts The a/c will cover the ground distance 220 NM with 468 kts groundspeed in: 220/468 = 0.47 hour = 28.2 min Applying the note, the fuel flow must be reduced by 3% per 10o C below standard TAT. So, it becomes: 923 - (3% x 923) = 895 kg/hr. For 0.47 hour flight time, the a/c will burn: 895 x 0.47 = 420 kgs per engine, so both engines will burn: 420 x 2 = 840 kgs. The nearest to our result option, is 837 kgs.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Finish the ENDURANCE/FUEL CALCULATION and determine ATC ENDURANCE for a twin jet aeroplane, with the help of the table provided. Contingency is 5 % of the planned trip fuel and fuel flow for extra fuel is 2400 kg/h.

key_points: ATC endurance is the maximum time that the aircraft can remain airborne taking into account the Final Reserve Fuel consumption as well, i
e
ATC edurance is up to dry tanks or ATC endurance is the elapsed time from take-off at which point you run out of all usable fuel, excluding the start-up and taxi fuel in your calculations
learning.explanation: ATC endurance is the maximum time that the aircraft can remain airborne taking into account the Final Reserve Fuel consumption as well, i.e. ATC edurance is up to dry tanks or ATC endurance is the elapsed time from take-off at which point you run out of all usable fuel, excluding the start-up and taxi fuel in your calculations. The question intentionally asks from the students to fill in the table, because the answer comes from the sum of the flight times which correspond to each fuel amount related with the airborne time (excluding taxi fuel). The Contingency fuel is: 5% x Trip fuel = 5% x 5 800 kg = 290 kg, which corresponds to a flight time of: 5% x 02:32 = 7.6 min. The Final Reserve fuel for a twin jet aeroplane is always fuel to fly for 00:30. The Extra fuel is: Ramp fuel - Taxi fuel - Trip fuel - Contingency fuel - Final Reserve fuel - Alternate fuel = 585 kg. The fuel flow for the Extra fuel is given as 2 400 kg/hr. So, the Extra fuel of 585 kg will permit to fly for: 585 kg / 2 400 kg/hr = 14.6 min. Thus, the ATC endurance is the sum of the following flight times: 02:32 + 00:07.6 + 00:42 + 00:30 + 00:14.6 = 04:06.2, which is very close to 04:07.

(2) Trip fuel, which should include: (i) fuel for take-off and climb from aerodrome elevation to initial cruising level/altitude, taking into account the expected departure routing; (ii) fuel from top of climb to top of descent, including any step climb/descent; (iii) fuel from top of descent to the point where the approach is initiated, taking into account the expected arrival procedure; and (iv) fuel for approach and landing at the destination aerodrome. content.question:
An aeroplane with reciprocating engines is planning to depart for an isolated destination Aerodrome as a Commercial Air Transport operation. Calculate the minimum amount of fuel required (to the nearest 10 kg), when overhead the isolated aerodrome, considering the following details.
Flight time: 2 hours and 30 minutes
Top of climb to top of descent time: 2 hours
Normal fuel consumption cruise: 780 kg per hour

key_points: Isolated aerodrome is one for which the alternate and final fuel reserve required to the nearest adequate destination alternate aerodrome is more than: for aeroplanes with reciprocating engines, fuel to fly for 45 minutes plus 15% of the flying time planned to be spent at cruising level or two hours, whichever is less or for aeroplanes with turbine engines, fuel to fly for two hours at normal cruise consumption above the destination aerodrome, including final reserve fuel

Thus, the reciprocating-engined aircraft must have a minimum amount of fuel required, when overhead the isolated aerodrome of: (45/60 x 780 kg) + (15% x 2 hr x 780 kg) = 585 kg + 234 kg = 819 kg, to the nearest 10 kg: 820 kg

Thus, the reciprocating-engined aircraft must have a minimum amount of fuel required, when overhead the isolated aerodrome of: (45/60 x 780 kg) + (15% x 2 hr x 780 kg) = 585 kg + 234 kg = 819 kg, to the nearest 10 kg: 820 kg.

Given the following data for the pre-flight calculations, determine the Trip Fuel required for a Commercial Air Transport flight. Assume the Basic Fuel Scheme WITHOUT variations applies.
Trip distance: 122 NM
TAS: 145 Kt
Headwind component: 15 kts
Average fuel flow: 4500 Kg/h
Extra Fuel: 0 kg
Discretionary Fuel: 0 kg

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new

" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept

The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. The aircraft experiences a headwind of 15 kt, thus its Groundspeed will be: GS = TAS - Headwind component = 145 kt - 15 kt = 130 kt. The flight time required to cover the ground distance of 122 NM is given by the formula: Flight time = Trip distance / Groundspeed = 122 NM / 130 kt = 0.9385 hr. The aircraft burns in average 4500 kg/hr. Therefore, within 0.93 hr of trip time its trip fuel will be: 0.9385 hr x 4500 kg/hr = 4223 kg.

Trip fuel from M to R: 7 800 kg

However, always calculate RCF 2, because there are questions where that is the largest

The annex shows the fuel breakdown for a flight from VOGO (Goa) to EGCC (Manchester). The pilots decide to carry an extra 1500 kg of fuel due to weather at the destination. If you check the table extra 1000 kg of fuel has a penalty of 236 kg fuel
This means it costs 236 kg of fuel to carry an extra 1000 kg of fuel
