content.question:
For pre-flight planning purposes, what is the minimum Ramp Fuel load for the Commercial Air Transport flight with a Jet aeroplane, given the following information? Assume the Basic Fuel Scheme WITHOUT variations applies.
Standard taxi fuel: 600 kg
Average cruise consumption: 10 000 kg/h
Holding fuel consumption at 1 500 ft above alternate airfield elevation: 8 000 kg/h
Flight time from departure to destination: 6 hours
Fuel for diversion to alternate: 10 200 kg
Extra Fuel: 0 kg
Discretionary Fuel: 0 kg

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new
The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel
" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no inquiries regarding the "new extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no inquiries regarding the "new extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. The minimum ramp fuel load is the sum of the following fuel amounts: Taxy fuel: 600 kg Trip fuel: Average cruise consumption x Flight time from departure to destination = 10 000 kg/h x 6 hours = 60 000 kg Contingency fuel: 5% of the Trip fuel = 5% x 60 000 kg = 3 000 kg Alternate fuel: 10 200 kg Additional fuel: N/A Final Reserve fuel (for a jet aeroplane fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft above alternate airfield elevation): 8 000 kg/hr / 2 = 4 000 kg Extra fuel: N/A Thus, the minimum ramp fuel load is 77 800 kg. NOTE: Only the holding fuel consumption at 1 500 ft above alternate airfield elevation is given, thus only the "5% Trip fuel" Contingency fuel can be calculated with the data given. The "5 min at holding speed at 1500 ft" Contingency fuel could be calculated, only if the holding fuel consumption at 1 500 ft above destination airfield elevation was given.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
You are planning a trip from London, Heathrow to St John's, Newfoundland and return. Operations have informed you that the fuel at St John's is much more expensive and want to know how much extra fuel you can tanker. Given the following information, what quantity of extra fuel is the aircraft able to carry?
Assume a departure / destination fuel price ratio of 0.915.
Cruise flight level: FL350
Air distance to be covered: 2000 NM
MTOM: 205 000 kg
MLM: 175 000 kg
Planned TOM: 185 000 kg
Fuel Tank Capacity: 40 000 kg
Planned T/O Fuel: 30 000 kg
Planned Trip Fuel: 18 000 kg

key_points: Refer of figure
If the cost of fuel at destination is higher than the cost at departure, then it is better to tanker cheaper fuel at the departure
But, when tankering additional fuel, the aircraft's mass increases, thus, the fuel consumption inceases too, incurring extra cost
learning.explanation: Refer of figure. If the cost of fuel at destination is higher than the cost at departure, then it is better to tanker cheaper fuel at the departure. But, when tankering additional fuel, the aircraft's mass increases, thus, the fuel consumption inceases too, incurring extra cost. The decision to tanker fuel is then based on a comparison of the two costs and the sector distance. The figure involves a comparison of cost (by calculation of the fuel price ratio: departure fuel price divided by destination fuel price) and then for a given sector distance, we get the "OPTIMUM AIRCRAFT TAKE-OFF MASS", which is the MTOM that permits fuel tanking. So: If the OPTIMUM TOM < Planned TOM, then do not fuel tank. If the OPTIMUM TOM > Planned TOM, then tanker an extra fuel amount equal to the difference: Planned TOM - OPTIMUM TOM. To get the OPTIMUM AIRCRAFT TAKE-OFF MASS, apply the following steps: Enter with the fuel price ratio of 0.915. Move horizontally to the right until cossing the air distance line 2 000 NM. Continue vertically down to get the OPTIMUM AIRCRAFT TAKE-OFF MASS 208 000 kg. Also, check if any limit is exceeded: The OPTIMUM AIRCRAFT TAKE-OFF MASS (208 000 kg) is more than the MTOM (205 000 kg). Thus, the aircraft can not carry more than: MTOM - Planned TOM = 205 000 kg - 185 000 kg = 20 000 kg of extra fuel for tankering purposes. Planned T/O fuel + Extra fuel = 30 000 kg + 20 000 kg = 50 000 kg, which is greater than the Tank capacity (40 000 kg) by 10 000 kg. So, the Extra fuel must be reduced by 10 000 kg to able to be loaded. So, the Revised Extra fuel because of being Tank capacity-limited is: 20 000 kg - 10 000 kg = 10 000 kg. Actual Landing Mass after tankering Extra fuel = Planned TOM - Trip fuel + Extra fuel = 185 000 kg - 18 000 kg + 10 000 kg = 177 000 kg, which is greater than the MLM (175 000 kg) by 2 000 kg. So, the previously Revised Extra fuel (10 000 kg) must be further reduced by 2 000 kg, so as not to exceed the MLM structural limit. So, the Final Revised Extra fuel, because of MLM-limited, is: 10 000 kg - 2 000 kg = 8 000 kg.

content.question: The fuel flow of a turbine engine is 200 kg/h with a relative fuel density of 0.8. If the relative density is 0.75 and any other flight conditions remain unchanged, the fuel flow will be:

Fuel flow with TAS 130 kt: 36 kg/hr
Fuel flow with TAS 140 kt: 42 kg/hr

key_points: Planned Fuel Consumption: Planned Groundspeed = Planned TAS + Planned headwind = 130 kt - 10 kt = 120 kt
Planned Flight Time = Distance A-B / Planned GS = 240 NM / 120 kt = 2 hr
learning.explanation: 1. Planned Fuel Consumption: Planned Groundspeed = Planned TAS + Planned headwind = 130 kt - 10 kt = 120 kt. Planned Flight Time = Distance A-B / Planned GS = 240 NM / 120 kt = 2 hr. Planned Fuel Consumption = Fuel flow with TAS 130 kt x Planned Flight Time = 36 kg/hr x 2 hr = 72 kg. 2. Actual Fuel Consumption: Actual Groundspeed = Actual TAS + Actual headwind = 140 kt - 25 kt = 115 kt. Actual Flight Time = Distance A-B / Actual GS = 240 NM / 115 kt = 2.09 hr. Actual Fuel Consumption = Fuel flow with TAS 140 kt x Actual Flight Time = 42 kg/hr x 2.09 hr = 87.78 kg. Therefore, the difference between Planned and Actual Fuel Consumption will be: 87.78 kg - 72 kg = 15.78 kg more than the planned, closest answer 16 kg.

content.question: The purpose of the 'Reduced Contingency Fuel (Decision point) Procedure' is to reduce the :

options.B: Contingency fuel and therefore to increase the final reserve fuel.
options.C: Minimum required fuel and therefore to increase the amount of additional fuel
options.D: Minimum required fuel and therefore to increase the load.

key_points: The purpose of the Decision Point Procedure is to reduce the minimum fuel required => it does this by reducing the contingency fuel requirement
The standard way of calculating contingency fuel was, historically, to calculate the highest of 5% of trip fuel or 5 min of holding fuel
Nowadays, with long haul flights (sometimes as long as 16h), 5% of trip fuel would be quite a lot
learning.explanation: The purpose of the Decision Point Procedure is to reduce the minimum fuel required => it does this by reducing the contingency fuel requirement. The standard way of calculating contingency fuel was, historically, to calculate the highest of 5% of trip fuel or 5 min of holding fuel. Nowadays, with long haul flights (sometimes as long as 16h), 5% of trip fuel would be quite a lot. Using the RCF Procedure, allows this contingency fuel to be significantly reduced. The RCF method makes use of an enroute alternate, and specifies that the fuel required must be the greater of the two different fuel calculations: Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES b) Reduced contingency fuel (RCF) procedure If the operator’s fuel policy includes pre-flight planning to a destination 1 aerodrome (commercial destination) with an RCF procedure using a decision point along the route and a destination 2 aerodrome (optional refuel destination), the amount of usable fuel, on board for departure, should be the greater of (b)(1) or (b)(2): (1) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; (ii) trip fuel to the destination 1 aerodrome, via the decision point; (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than 5 % of the estimated fuel consumption from the decision point to the destination 1 aerodrome; (iv) alternate fuel or no alternate fuel if the decision point is at less than 6 hours from the destination 1 aerodrome and the requirements of CAT. OP. MPA.180(b)(2), are fulfilled; (v) final reserve fuel; (vi) additional fuel; and (vii) extra fuel if required by the commander. (2) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; (ii) trip fuel to the destination 2 aerodrome, via the decision point; (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than the amount calculated in accordance with (a)(3) above from departure aerodrome to the destination 2 aerodrome; (iv) alternate fuel, if a destination 2 alternate aerodrome is required; (v) final reserve fuel; (vi) additional fuel; and (vii) extra fuel if required by the commander

key_points: TAKE-OFF MASS (TOM) - The mass of the aeroplane including everything and everyone contained within it at the start of the take-off run

=> Take-Off Mass (TOM) = Dry Operating Mass (DOM) + Traffic Load (TL) + Take off Fuel (TOF)* TOF * = Trip Fuel + Contingency Fuel + Alternate Fuel + Final Reserve TOF = 2 040 kg + 102 kg + 1 100 kg + 983 kg = 4 225 kg Take Off Mass (TOM) = 33 510 kg + 7 600 kg + 4 225 kg = 45 335 kg LANDING MASS (LM) - As we reach our Destination, we will have consumed Trip fuel
Therefore, Landing mass equals Take-off Mass minus Trip Fuel
learning.explanation: TAKE-OFF MASS (TOM) - The mass of the aeroplane including everything and everyone contained within it at the start of the take-off run. => Take-Off Mass (TOM) = Dry Operating Mass (DOM) + Traffic Load (TL) + Take off Fuel (TOF)* TOF * = Trip Fuel + Contingency Fuel + Alternate Fuel + Final Reserve TOF = 2 040 kg + 102 kg + 1 100 kg + 983 kg = 4 225 kg Take Off Mass (TOM) = 33 510 kg + 7 600 kg + 4 225 kg = 45 335 kg LANDING MASS (LM) - As we reach our Destination, we will have consumed Trip fuel. Therefore, Landing mass equals Take-off Mass minus Trip Fuel. => Landing Mass (LM) = Take off Mass (TOM) - Trip Fuel LM = 45 335 kg - 2 040 kg = 43 295 kg Note: Contingency fuel is loaded for deviations from planned and actual trip fuel, i.e. for unforeseen factors. They might be deviations from forecast weather conditions, deviations from the planned route or from planned cruising levels and/or altitudes. Under normal conditions, contingency fuel should remain in our tanks upon reaching our destination.

MPA.150(b) Fuel policy PLANNING CRITERIA — AEROPLANES (b) Reduced contingency fuel (RCF) procedure If the operator’s fuel policy includes pre-flight planning to a destination 1 aerodrome (commercial destination) with an RCF procedure using a decision point along the route and a destination 2 aerodrome (optional refuel destination), the amount of usable fuel, on board for departure, should be the greater of (b)(1) or (b)(2): FIRST SCENARIO (DECISION POINT OVER C): (1) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; N/A (ii) trip fuel to the destination 1 aerodrome, via the decision point; Distance A-C-B: 2000 NM Flight Time = 2 000 NM / 400 kt = 5 h FF: 2 000 kg/h Therefore, Trip Fuel = 5 h x 2000 kg/h = 10 000 kg (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than 5 % of the estimated fuel consumption from the decision point to the destination 1 aerodrome; Distance C-B: 200 NM + 900 NM = 1100 NM Flight time: 1100 NM / 400 kt = 2.75 h 2.75 h x 2000 kg/h = 5500 kg Contingency = 5% x 5500 kg = 275 kg (iv) alternate fuel or no alternate fuel if the decision point is at less than 6 hours from the destination 1 aerodrome and the requirements of CAT. OP. MPA.180(b)(2), are fulfilled; N/A (v) final reserve fuel; N/A (vi) additional fuel; and N/A (vii) extra fuel if required by the commander. N/A FOR (b)(1) – we have a value of 10 000 kg + 275 kg = 10 275 kg (2) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; N/A (ii) trip fuel to the destination 2 aerodrome, via the decision point; Distance A-C-ALT: 900 NM + 200 NM = 1100 NM Flight time: 1100 NM / 400 kt = 2.75 h FF: 2 000 kg/h Therefore, Trip Fuel = 2.75 h x 2000 kg/h = 5500 kg (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than the amount calculated in accordance with (a)(3)(*) above from departure aerodrome to the destination 2 aerodrome; 5500 kg x 5% = 275 kg (iv) alternate fuel, if a destination 2 alternate aerodrome is required; N/A (v) final reserve fuel; N/A (vi) additional fuel; and N/A (vii) extra fuel if required by the commander. N/A FOR (b)(2) – we have a value of 5500 kg + 275 kg = 5775 kg => We will, therefore, choose the highest value which corresponds to (b)(1) => 10 275 kg. SECOND SCENARIO (DECISION POINT OVER D): (1) The sum of: (ii) trip fuel to the destination 1 aerodrome, via the decision point; Distance ADB: 2000 NM Flight Time = 2 000 NM / 400 kt = 5 h FF: 2 000 kg/h Therefore, Trip Fuel = 5 h x 2000 kg/h = 10 000 kg (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than 5 % of the estimated fuel consumption from the decision point to the destination 1 aerodrome; Distance DB: 900 NM Flight time: 900 NM / 400 kt = 2.25 h 2.25 h x 2000 kg/h = 4500 kg Contingency = 5% x 4500 kg = 225 kg (.) FOR (b)(1) – we have a value of 10 000 kg + 225 kg = 10 225 kg (2) The sum of: (i) taxi fuel; N/A (ii) trip fuel to the destination 2 aerodrome, via the decision point; Distance A-D-ERA: 900 NM + 200NM + 200 NM = 1300 NM Flight time: 1300 NM / 400 kt = 3.25 h FF: 2 000 kg/h Therefore, Trip Fuel = 3.25 h x 2000 kg/h = 6500 kg (iii) contingency fuel equal to not less than the amount calculated in accordance with (a)(3)(*) above from departure aerodrome to the destination 2 aerodrome; 6500 kg x 5% = 325 kg (.) FOR (b)(2) – we have a value of 6 500 kg + 325 kg = 6 825 kg => We will, therefore, choose the highest value which corresponds to (b)(1) => 10 225 kg. We must compare both greatest values obtained (10 275 kg and 10 225 kg). We can conclude that, when moving DP from C to D, the Fuel required will decrease by 10 275 kg – 10 225 kg = 50 kg. NOTE: An exhaustive explanation has been created so you can understand where the value comes from but no calculation is needed: it needs understanding that when you move the DP closer to destination the amount of fuel needed decrease as in Decision Point procedure the contingency fuel for destination is only from DP to destination. Discretionary Fuel: 0 kg

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new
The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel
" EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The modifications resulting from the updated fuel policy regulations, which came into effect on October 30, 2022, are only changes in wording but nothing really new. The terminology "extra fuel" has been replaced with "discretionary fuel." EASA has clarified that the calculations and procedures pertaining to fuel calculations will remain unchanged, and there will be no new questions regarding the new "extra fuel" concept. extra fuel, include anticipated delays or specific operational constraints that can be predicted discretionary fuel, include a quantity at the sole discretion of the commander For reference, additional information can be found in EASA's AIR OPS documentation. The total amount of fuel required for this commetcial flight should include the following fuel quantities: Taxi fuel + Trip fuel + Contingency fuel + Alternate Fuel + Final reserve fuel. Therefore, we have: Taxi Fuel: The Taxi fuel includes the fuel expected to be used prior to take-off and the fuel consumed by the use of the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU). In this question, the APU usage at the parking position is 0 minutes. For the calculation of the taxi fuel, we take into consideration the fuel consumption only at the departure aerodrome. Fuel flow during taxi: 11 kg per minute Planned taxi time: 10 minutes Taxi fuel = 11 kg/min x 10 min = 110 kg Trip Fuel: Average fuel flow is 2618 kg/h. We must calculate the flight time. We have TAS = 421 kt and average wind component = - 24 kt (headwind) ⇒ Ground Speed = TAS - Headwind component = 421 kt - 24 kt = 397 kt. With a Ground Speed of 397 kt (397 kt = 397 NM/h), the time required to cover the distance of 748 NM is: Time = Distance/Ground Speed = 748/397 Given that the flight time is 748/397 h and the average fuel flow is 2638 kg/h, the Trip fuel is: Trip fuel = (748/397) h x 2618 kg/h = 4 932.65 kg (approx. 4 933 kg) Contingency fuel: Question states that Contingency fuel is 5% of the Trip fuel. Since the Trip fuel is 4 933 kg, the Contingency fuel is: Contingency fuel = 0.05 x 4 933 kg = 246.65 kg (approx. 247 kg) Alternate fuel: Question states that Alternate fuel equals 550 kg. Final Reserve fuel: According to EASA Air Ops (AMC1 CAT. OP. MPA.150(b) Fuel Policy), the Final reserve fuel for an aeroplane with turbine engines, is the fuel to fly for 30 minutes at holding speed at 1500 ft above aerodrome elevation in standard conditions. From the question, the holding fuel flow is 2 250 kg/h. As a result, the Final reserve fuel is: Final reserve fuel = (30 x 2 250)/60 kg = 1 125 kg The total amount of fuel required for this commercial flight is: Total fuel = 110 kg + 4 933 kg + 247 kg + 550 kg + 1 125 kg = 6 965 kg.

content.question:
An aircraft is flying along a true course of 276º and the actual wind is different than the forecast wind. The forecast wind is 240/15 and the actual wind is 290/25. The airspeed remains the same. Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival.
2) The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left.

key_points: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival

" Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind)
This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed
learning.explanation: 1) "The lower ground speed will result in a later time of arrival." Correct: With the actual wind coming from 290 degrees at 25 kt (instead of 240/15), while the aircraft is heading along a true course of 276º, it means that the aircraft is flying somewhat into a stronger headwind component (and weaker crosswind). This stronger headwind component will reduce the ground speed. A lower ground speed means it will take more time to cover the same distance, resulting in a later time of arrival. 2) "The wind correction angle will change from a value to the right to a value to the left." Incorrect: The change in wind direction and speed from the forecast (240/15) to the actual (290/25) wind means the wind correction angle will likely change. The wind correction angle is the angle by which the pilot adjusts the heading to compensate for the crosswind component of the wind. Under the forecasted wind, the wind is causing the aircraft to drift to the right, necessitating a wind correction angle to the left. In contrast, with the wind now arriving from the right of the aircraft, it will tend to push the aircraft to the left, thereby requiring a wind correction angle to the right.

content.question: The minimum climb gradient for obstacle clearance is 4%. TAS for the best rate of climb is 230 kt. Given a tailwind of 15 kt, what minimum rate of climb can be achieved?

key_points: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind
It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected
HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration
learning.explanation: Rate of climb is independent of wind, only climb angle (and flight path climb gradient) will be affected by a headwind or tailwind. It means you will reach a specific altitude in the same time interval, but your ground distance will be affected. HOWEVER, for obstacle clearance purposes, wind should be taken into consideration. Therefore, we have: Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) We can assume ROC remains constant even if we experience a tailwind of 15 kt. Rate of climb (ft/min) = Climb Gradient (%) x GS (kt) If we convert GS unit from kt to ft/min → 245 kt x 6 080 ft / 60 min = 24 827 ft/min Rate of climb (ft/min) = 4% x 24 827 ft/min = 993 ft/min

An aircraft is flying VFR using a VOR to navigate. The aircraft is following Radial 128º outbound from the VOR. Determine the expected Wind Correction Angle (WCA), given:

TAS: 155 kt
Variation: 15º W

key_points: The aircraft is following radial 128º => 128º Magnetic Track

Let’s start by converting Magnetic Track into True Track: Variation 15ºW: Variation West => Magnetic BEST True Track = Magnetic Track – Variation = 128º - 015º = 113º Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 080º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
learning.explanation: The aircraft is following radial 128º => 128º Magnetic Track. Let’s start by converting Magnetic Track into True Track: Variation 15ºW: Variation West => Magnetic BEST True Track = Magnetic Track – Variation = 128º - 015º = 113º Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 080º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 155 kt. Mark the wind velocity 35 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 113º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 9ºR drift and a track of 122º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 113º. This occurs at a heading of 104º with 7ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 124 kt. Wind correction angle (WCA) is the angle (º) between the Course and the Heading that is required for the aircraft to track that Course when there is wind. Wind Correction Angle is the same value as drift but it is applied in the opposite sense: (-)7ºL WCA

learning.explanation: To solve this exercise, we must ensure that all directions are either in True or Magnetic. We can accomplish this by either converting the course to True or changing the wind to Magnetic. We can use the mnemonic: "Magnetic Variation East, Magnetic Least; Magnetic Variation West, Magnetic Best" In this case, we've decided to convert the course to True: Course 127º (M), Variation 15ºE 127º(M) + 15ºE = 142º (T) For True Airspeed (TAS) at Flight Level 70 (FL70), we need to interpolate between 6 000 and 8 000 ft and ISA Dev. +20ºC, ISA Dev. 0º. ISA Dev. +20ºC 6 000 ft 172 kt 7 000 ft (172 kt + 169 kt) / 2 = 170.5 kt 8 000 ft 169 kt ISA Dev. 0ºC 6 000 ft 171 kt 7 000 ft (171 kt + 169 kt) / 2 = 170 kt 8 000 ft 169 kt FL70, ISA Dev. +10ºC = (170 kt + 170.5) / 2 = 170.25 kt Now, using the flight computer to determine drift, remember that we are using a track, not a heading. Place the center of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (170 knots). Position the wind direction (110º) under the true index. Mark the wind velocity (50 knots) upwards from the center. Note: When the question provides a track, mark wind velocity upwards from the center. When the heading is known, mark wind velocity downwards from the center. Align your true track (142º) under the true index. Slide the wind velocity mark to True Air Speed (170 knots). The Wind Correction Angle (WCA) is read between the centerline and the wind velocity mark, which indicates a 9º left correction (-9º). WCA and drift are opposite in direction and of equal magnitude. So, a WCA of 9ºL corresponds to a drift of 9ºR.

learning.explanation: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking. In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination. It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated. The VOR cannot be used for navigation due to the lack of serviceable equipment on the aircraft. The tall mast may be an acceptable turning point, but might be difficult to identify in the Sun and the haze, and the long legs with reduced visibility could lead the aircraft to being off course and have a higher chance of getting the pilot lost than following the highway and river. The 4th route is not even on the map, and is similar to using the mast, though it is much likely easier to find, but is large and therefore less accurate as a position fix.

learning.explanation: First step of our calculation is going to involve the calculation of the head/tailwind component. Knowing our true course and the wind, we can easily calculate the wind components using a formula: cos (wind angle) × wind speed. In our case the course = 090° and the wind is reported at 030° / 100 kts. Therefore, the wind angle is 60° (90° - 030°). Wind component = cos 60° = 0.5 * 100 =50 kts headwind GS = TAS - HW => 350 - 50 = 300 kts Distance = Speed * Time 100 = 300 * t => 0.33 h * 60 =20 minutes Closest answer is 21 minutes.

content.question:
An aircraft is being flown in the cruise. Determine the expected drift, given:
Course: 210°(M)
TAS: 179 kt
Forecast wind: 330°/50 kt
Variation: 20°W

key_points: Refer to figure To solve this exercise, we must ensure that all directions are either in True or Magnetic
We can accomplish this by either converting the course to True or changing the wind to Magnetic

We can use the mnemonic: "Magnetic Variation East, Magnetic Least; Magnetic Variation West, Magnetic Best" In this case, we've decided to convert the course to True: Course 210º (M), Variation 20ºW 210º(M) - 20ºW = 190º (T) Using the flight computer to determine drift, remember that we are using a track, not a heading
learning.explanation: Refer to figure To solve this exercise, we must ensure that all directions are either in True or Magnetic. We can accomplish this by either converting the course to True or changing the wind to Magnetic. We can use the mnemonic: "Magnetic Variation East, Magnetic Least; Magnetic Variation West, Magnetic Best" In this case, we've decided to convert the course to True: Course 210º (M), Variation 20ºW 210º(M) - 20ºW = 190º (T) Using the flight computer to determine drift, remember that we are using a track, not a heading. Place the center of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (179 knots). Position the wind direction (330º) under the true index. Mark the wind velocity (50 knots) upwards from the center. Note: When the question provides a track, mark wind velocity upwards from the center. When the heading is known, mark wind velocity downwards from the center. Align your true track (190º) under the true index. Slide the wind velocity mark to True Air Speed (179 kt). The Wind Correction Angle (WCA) is read between the centerline and the wind velocity mark, which indicates a 10º right correction (+10º). WCA and drift are opposite in direction and of equal magnitude. So, a WCA of 10ºR corresponds to a drift of 10ºL.

content.question:
Given the following information, what is the Air distance (NAM) covered?
TAS: 120 kt
Headwind component: 20 kt
Ground Distance: 200 NGM

key_points: A relationship exists between air distance and ground distance, as well as between True airspeed and Ground speed, given by the following equation, which is equal to the Flight time: TIME = NAM / TAS = NGM / GS Solving for NAM and substituting the known values of the above equation, we get: NAM = NGM x TAS / GS = 200 NGM x 120 kt / (120 - 20) kt = 240 NAM
OR The flight time to cover 200 NGM is: Time = NGM / GS= 200 NM / (120 - 20) kt = 2 hr
So, the Air distance will be: NAM = TAS x Time = 120 kt x 2 hr = 240 NAM

content.question:
An aircraft is flying under VFR on a track of 168°M. The elevation of the highest obstacle within 5 NM of the intended track of the aircraft is 4200 ft. Given the following information, provided by an aerodrome at 1400 ft elevation, what is the minimum flight level which will give an obstacle clearance 1000 ft?
QNH: 1026 hPa
Temperature: 12°C below ISA
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft
The ISA deviation is given: -12oC

After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft
learning.explanation: This is a typical "Altimetry Error question", which requires both pressure and temperature correction: The Minimum True Altitude to clear the obstacle is: 4200 ft + 1000 ft = 5200 ft. The ISA deviation is given: -12oC. After applying the temperature correction, the minimum true altitude will be: Min True Altitude - [4 x (True Altitude from Pressure Datum/1000) x ISA deviation] = 5200 ft - [4 x (5200 ft - 1400 ft)/1000) x (-12oC)] = 5200 ft + 182 ft = 5382 ft. After applying the pressure correction, the minimum pressure altitude will be: 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - QNH) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft + [(1013 hPa - 1026 hPa) x 30 ft] = 5382 ft - (13 hPa x 30 ft) = 5382 ft - 390 ft = 4992 ft. According to the "ICAO VFR Semi-Circular Rule": For Easterly Magnetic tracks (000o - 179o), the Flight Levels are: Odd FLs + 500 ft (FL35, FL55, FL75, etc.). For Westerly Magnetic tracks (180o - 359o), the Flight Levels are: Even FLs + 500 ft (FL25, FL45, FL65, etc.). The aircraft flies an easterly magnetic track of 168o(M), thus the Minimum Flight Level, which provides obstacle clearance, after both pressure and temperature correction, that must be selected is: FL55.

The aircraft follows a Westerly magnetic track from Schärding Süben (LOLS) to Pfarrkirchen (EDNP) aerodromes. According to the ICAO VFR semi-circular rule, for a westerly magnetic track, Even FLs/Altitudes + 500 ft should be flown (2 500 ft, 4 500 ft, 6 500 ft, etc.). So, a cruise altitude of 6 500 ft can be followed, which apart from being according to the ICAO rule, it provides obstacle clearance too. It is a bit higher than you might usually use for this route, but it is perfectly acceptable nonetheless. Line features (rivers, motorways, railways, etc.) are highly recommended for navigation in VFR flights. The Rott river, as a line feature, is very helpful, because it is aligned with the Westerly flight direction and runs very close to the route. The A3 motorway does not follow the route. The aircraft during its descent towards Pfarrkirchen (EDNP) destination aerodrome, will be within a Class F airspace with vertical limits from 1 500 ft AGL - 2500 ft AGL, initially, and as approaching to the destination aerodrome will remain within a Class F airspace with vertical limits from GND - 2500 ft AGL.

content.question: Along the route the highest obstacle is 13 421 feet AMSL. If the QNH is 989 hPa, the MT is 311° and the temperature is 10 degrees below ISA, the lowest appropriate VFR flight level that you could choose in order to clear this obstacle by a minimum of 2000 feet is:

key_points: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL
Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL

Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC
learning.explanation: You need to fly 2 000 ft above an obstacle, 13 421 ft AMSL. Therefore, you need to fly at a True Altitude of 15 421 ft AMSL. Knowing our True Altitude, let's find Indicated Altitude: Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Temperature Correction + Pressure correction Temperature Correction Rule of thumb: correction of 4% for each 10ºC deviation from ISA ISA deviation = -10ºC. Therefore we will apply a correction of 4%. 15 421 ft x 4% = 617 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-10ºC), Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude. Indicated Altitude = 15 421 ft + 617 ft = 16 038 ft Pressure correction If the current QNH is 989 hPa, the difference to standard pressure will be: 1013 hPa – 989 hPa = 24 hPa Assuming a barometric lapse rate of 30ft/hPa: 24 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 720 ft Since our current QNH is lower than standard, Indicated altitude is greater than True altitude: 16 038 ft + 720 ft = 16 758 ft. This altitude is also called Pressure altitude (PA). Remember that you are flying Westbound on a VFR flight - Therefore, your flight level should be EVEN and you should use the intermediate 500 ft => The Lowest usable flight level will be FL185 Further info on Cruising Levels: VFR and IFR aircraft are allocated different levels to fly at: IFR flights use whole 1000's of feet (e.g. 1000, 3000 etc. when flying eastbound, and 2000, 4000 etc. when flying westbound) VFR flights use the intermediate 500 ft. levels (e.g. 3500, 5500 etc. when flying eastbound and 4500, 6500 when flying westbound)

Both calculating based on climb rate & time and calculating based on TAS & wind corrections are viable options. However, calculating based on TAS & wind corrections is usually most effective for longer legs of a journey and is when this method is commonly used. This is due to the reason that wind has greater impact over longer legs. Also, wind can vary significantly at different altitudes along the climb path so, it is more reliable for short distances to calculate based on climb rate and time. For this reason, calculating based on climb rate and time is most suitable for the situation.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft is doing some aerial work while flying VFR in the vicinity of LOGI (N47°29.7' E014°29.9'). Which flight level is most suitable for the activity?
Temperature = ISA -15°C
QNH = 1018 hPa

key_points: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude)
We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation
The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft
learning.explanation: Calculation of terrain clearance and flight level Upon inspection of LOGI, we can see that it is situated between 4 different areas with different Grid MORAs (Minimum Off-Route Altitude). We must take the highest Grid MORA, in order to ensure that we have a safe vertical separation. The aircraft must fly at 10 800 ft. This must be the true altitude of the aircraft. This altitude must be corrected for any temperature ISA deviation and then any difference in pressure from standard (1013 hPa), to get the pressure altitude, allowing us to work out the lowest usable flight level. The first step is to determine the temperature correction. The ISA deviation is ISA -15°C. Based on the 4% rule and its calculation mentioned in the rules below, the height correction for the temperature can be calculated as follows: Height correction for temperature = 4 × (-15) × (10 800/1000) = -648 ft. The temperature correction is added to the true altitude as per the rules below, to give an indicated altitude of 11 448 ft. Next, we need to compute the pressure correction by considering the deviation from the standard mean sea level pressure of 1013 hPa: 1018 hPa - 1013 hPa = 5 hPa. Since the barometric lapse rate near the surface is 30 ft/hPa, the pressure correction can be calculated as follows: Pressure correction = (5) x 30 ft/hPa = 150 ft. This value needs to be subtracted from the indicated altitude as per the rules below: Pressure Altitude = 11 448 - 150 = 11 298 ft Since we are a VFR flight, we are required to fly at altitudes that are whole thousands plus 500 feet. The only altitude above 11 298 ft which also obeys this rule is FL115. RULES. The following rules should be considered for altimetry calculations: All calculations are based on rounded pressure values to the nearest lower hPa. The value for the barometric lapse rate between MSL and 500 hPa to be used is 30 ft/hPa as an acceptable approximation of the barometric lapse rate. To determine the true altitude/height, the following rule of thumb, called the ‘4 %-rule’, shall be used: the altitude/height changes by 4% for each 10°C temperature deviation from ISA. For simplification: Height correction for the temp = 4 × (ISA DEV) × Indicated alt/1000 = _____ ft If no further information is given, the deviation of the outside-air temperature from ISA is considered to be the same throughout the whole layer. The elevation of the aerodrome has to be taken into account. The temperature correction has to be considered for the layer between the station (usually an aerodrome) and the position of the aircraft. HIGHER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE > PRESSURE ALTITUDE LOWER PRESSURE; INDICATED ALTITUDE < PRESSURE ALTITUDE WARMER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE > INDICATED ALTITUDE COLDER THAN ISA; TRUE ALTITUDE < INDICATED ALTITUDE DEFINITIONS. Pressure Altitude: The altimeter indication with standard pressure (1013.2 hPa) set. Indicated Altitude: The altimeter indication with local QNH set. True altitude: The actual altitude of the aircraft above mean sea level.

You are approaching airfield MÜHLDORF (EDMY, N48° 16.77' E012° 30.02') from the east on track 270°. The descent should be planned to arrive at an altitude of 3 500 ft approximately abeam of airfield ALTÖTTING.

With a rate of descent = 500 ft/min, it will take us: 9 000 ft / 500 ft min = 18 min to reach 3500 ft from FL125. Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 300º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 110 kt. Mark the wind velocity 16 kt down from the centre point. content.question: What is the required horizontal distance, measured from an airfield at sea level, to initiate a descent from an altitude of 17 000 ft and reach an altitude of 2 000 ft while being 10 NM away from the airfield? With a rate of descent of 1 500 ft/min, the aircraft will take 10 minutes to descend 15 000 ft (15 000 ft ÷ 1 500 ft/min)

content.question: Refer to Nantes chart 19-1 from Jeppesen GSPRM. An aeroplane is departing from Nantes to conduct VFR flight to the northwest and will cross waypoint (NW). What will be the best visual check point to check the position at waypoint (NW).

options.D: By looking for the highway junction, which is the only junction in that area.

key_points: During VFR flights you can best pinpoint your position using unique line features, such as railway lines, motorways or junctions of those
Small built-up areas are recommended, when they are isolated and close to obvious ground features, such as lakes, reservoirs, junctions and nearby to identify it

learning.explanation: During VFR flights you can best pinpoint your position using unique line features, such as railway lines, motorways or junctions of those. Small built-up areas are recommended, when they are isolated and close to obvious ground features, such as lakes, reservoirs, junctions and nearby to identify it. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. In the vicinity of Nantes aerodrome there are many identical ground features, such as lighted masts, which can cause confusion to the pilot's flight monitoring, since they cannot be considered as unique. In this case, the best option to check the position at waypoint "NW", is by looking for the highway junction, which is the only junction in that area and at a distance from the other motorway junctions, so as to ensure that the planned route is followed and to correct promptly any inattention which may cause any inadvertent drift.

content.question: An aircraft is climbing from 3000 ft to 8000 ft on a 3° path at an average GS of 210 kt. The altitude of 8000 ft will be reached in (1) _____ and the ground distance covered will be (2) _____.

The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4
learning.explanation: 1. For a climb with 3◦ path the rate of climb can be found by the formula: Rate of Climb (fpm) = 5 x Ground Speed (knots) = 5 x 210 = 1050 fpm 2. The time to climb from 3000 ft to 8000 ft is: Time to climb (min) = Height difference (ft) / ROC (fpm) = (8000 ft - 3000 ft) / 1050 fpm = 4.76 min or 4 min and 46 sec. 3. The Ground distance covered during the climb is: Ground distance (NM) = GS (knots) x Time (hours) = 210 kt x 4.76/60 hr = 16.7 NM.

content.question:
A mountain 6 011 ft AMSL will be crossed. What is the lowest VFR ICAO level the aircraft must fly to obtain a clearance of 2 000 ft? Given:
Variation: 10ºW
Aircraft's Track: 356º T
Aircraft's HDG: 355º M
QNH: 990 hPa
Assume 1 hPa = 30 ft

key_points: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa)
Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA
learning.explanation: First considerations: To obtain a terrain clearance of 2 000 ft, the aircraft must be flown at a true altitude of = 6 011 ft + 2 000 ft = 8 011 ft When flying Flight Levels, the altimeter is set to Standard Pressure (1013 hPa). Pressure Correction: Note: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than IA. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than IA. Local pressure equals 990 hPa which is lower than standard pressure by 1013 hPa - 990 hPa = 23 hPa. 23 hPa x 30 ft/hPa = 690 ft Indicated Altitude = True Altitude + Pressure Correction Indicated Altitude = 8 011 ft + 690 ft = 8 701 ft Semicircular Flight Rules: IFR flight levels/altitudes are divisible by 1 000 ft (i.e. 7 000 ft, 8 000 ft, 9 000 ft). The VFR rules of flight level and/or altitude selection is the same as IFR ones with adding 500 ft to all levels. The default worldwide semi-circular rule is the East/West orientation of the flight level parity: Your aircraft has track between 0° and 179°, your flight level or altitude must be odd; Your aircraft has track between 180° and 359°, your flight level or altitude must be even. The appropriate altitude or flight level must be determined using the magnetic track (not heading). In this case, True Track (TT) equals 356º, applying the magnetic Variation provided (10ºW), we can find the Magnetic Track (MT) Variation West, magnetic direction BEST; Variation East, Magnetic Direction LEAST. MT = 356º + 10º = 006º According to the rules shared above, an ODD flight level + 500 ft must be used: First available Flight level above 8 701 ft => FL95

content.question:
Refer to ED-4 VFR chart from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017. An aircraft on a VFR flight intends to fly overhead aerodrome Straubing (EDMS) (48°54' N, 012°31' E). Given the following information, what is the minimum indicated altitude required to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft?
Altimeter temperature error with an OAT -7°C at Straubing (EDMS): 240 ft
QNH at Straubing (EDMS): 998 hPa
Altimeter setting: 998 hPa
(Round altitudes and elevations to the nearest 10 ft)

key_points: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft
The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C
The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere
learning.explanation: The upper vertical limit of the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace is 2 500 ft Above Ground Level (AGL) and the aerodrome's elevation is 1 054 ft. The altimeter temperature error correction is given, 240 ft, because of flying within a cold atmosphere with an OAT of -7°C. The correction must be added, because the indicated altitude will be higher than the true altitude in a cold atmosphere. The aircraft flies with an altimeter setting, 998 hPa, equal to the QNH of the Straubing aerodrome, thus no pressure correction is required. Therefore, the minimum indicated altitude to clear the Straubing (EDMS) Class F airspace by 500 ft is: 2 500 ft + 1 054 ft + 240 ft + 500 ft = 4 294 ft.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct? The climb gradient is:

options.A: Always smaller than the angle of climb.
options.B: Always larger than the angle of climb.
options.D: The same as the angle of climb.

key_points: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage
The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent
The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb
learning.explanation: Climb gradient is the ratio between distance travelled over the ground and altitude gained and is expressed as a percentage. The angle of climb can be defined as the angle between a horizontal plane representing the Earth's surface and the actual flight path followed by the aircraft during its ascent. The climb gradient numerical value is always larger than the angle of climb. For instance, 3º angle of climb equals approximately 5% gradient.
